thread.title: Rugby rivalries: there are two sides to every great story
thread.title_full: Rugby rivalries: there are two sides to every great story - Telegraph

author: The Telegraph
title: Rugby rivalries: there are two sides to every great story
text: Wales Only two victories separate England and Wales after 126 matches. England lead 58-56, with 12 draws, but went winless in Cardiff for 28 years before their 1991 victory. Scotland The two countries contested the first rugby international in 1871. Perhaps their most famous meetings were the 1990 grand-slam decider at Murrayfield, which went the way of a fired-up Scotland, and the World Cup semi-final 19 months later in which England exacted revenge. France A fixture that has become known as Le Crunch. Mick Skinner’s tackle at the Parc des Princes in 1991; Philippe Saint-Andre’s length-of-thefield try at Twickenham that same year – there have been many memorable moments. New Zealand England have beaten the All Blacks just seven times in more than a century, and only once in the past 10 years, 38-21 at Twickenham in 2012. Brian Moore says: • For me, the most intense rivalry was with the French. Add historical enmity to political, cultural and philosophical differences and you had a potent recipe for conflict. The games were brutal, tinged with brilliance – mainly from their mercurial backs. • For more information on health and lifestyle, visit vitality.com
